content.body: Structs have items, although I sometimes accidentally call them members, which makes me wonder why we called them items in the first place...
And would you refer to something like a navigable's `target name` as an item?
content.formatted_body: And would you refer to something like a navigable's target name as an item?

content.body: To the extent that we decide they are structs, yes. Which I guess they are, although not explicitly.
Domenic: thoughts on https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/50295? I didn't actually want that to land until you weighed in.
content.formatted_body: Domenic: thoughts on https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/50295? I didn't actually want that to land until you weighed in.

content.body: Hmm I wonder how I missed that. I think the 1 and 2 direction seems reasonable. This seems like an area where doing the simplest-possible thing is best, and since "anything starting with on" wasn't good, the 1 plus 2 option seems like the next-simplest.

I'm thinking of writing a basic tool to convert the HTML spec to Bikeshed, getting it only 80% correct, so that Tab could benchmark against that instead. annevk other than performance, do you know of any other issues that would have to be addressed to make migration realistic? I can spend a bit of time on this if it feels within reach.
content.formatted_body: I'm thinking of writing a basic tool to convert the HTML spec to Bikeshed, getting it only 80% correct, so that Tab could benchmark against that instead. annevk other than performance, do you know of any other issues that would have to be addressed to make migration realistic? I can spend a bit of time on this if it feels within reach.

content.body: Grateful that Tab has time to work on bikeshed

foolip: you could maybe use Microsoft's work on the W3C fork some number of years ago for benchmark purposes? But maybe doing it fresh is better, as much has changed. I don't know of any other issues, but I think it's primarily Domenic that cares about the particulars here as I was willing to accept longer CI runs.
content.formatted_body: foolip: you could maybe use Microsoft's work on the W3C fork some number of years ago for benchmark purposes? But maybe doing it fresh is better, as much has changed. I don't know of any other issues, but I think it's primarily Domenic that cares about the particulars here as I was willing to accept longer CI runs.

content.body: I guess we’d want to decide how much a slowdown in build times for CI runs — and for local builds by patch/PR contributors — would be acceptable
In my local environment currently, the build takes only about 25 seconds to run
So even if the Bikeshed build ended up about 10 times as slow, that’s still only 4 minutes
…which maybe is still fast relative to say, building code for a large software project
(certainly faster than running a clean build for any browser engine)

https://matrixlogs.bakkot.com/irc-whatwg/plaintext/2018-06.txt has some prior discussion involving many of the same people. Assuming Domenic still feels the same about this, the numbers would have to be very close to what you get today locally.
content.formatted_body: https://matrixlogs.bakkot.com/irc-whatwg/plaintext/2018-06.txt has some prior discussion involving many of the same people. Assuming Domenic still feels the same about this, the numbers would have to be very close to what you get today locally.

content.body: I am constantly editing and rebuilding the full spec locally, yeah, anything slower than the current would dramatically curtail my contributions
Html-build's -f mode (single page only, no highlight pass, no lint pass) is like < 5 seconds on my desktop, maybe 10-15 on laptop?
OK yeah, I just tried now, and building with -f is 4–5 seconds on my laptop
so 10 times slower than _that_ would be 40–50 seconds
content.formatted_body: so 10 times slower than that would be 40–50 seconds

content.body: I’d like to be optimistic, but I find it unlikely that a Bikeshed-based build is going to ever be able to come close to the current build times
I mean, at least a Python-based Bikeshed
but maybe there’s some magic there I’m unaware of
One thing about the existing Wattsi code is that its HTML parser is extremely exceptionally fast
and another thing is, I think maybe even in the -f case, the Wattsi build parses the source multiple times
Why would it parse it multiple times?

Greetings to all. I am glad that this chat on whatwg exists, I just discovered it!

I was wondering if there is any documentation on the "domain language" concepts related to DOM, as it would be a good tool for me to have that documentation to refer to while studying the living DOM documentation.

content.formatted_body: jose.pepe: https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/ should explain all the terms. Anything in particular that trips you up?

content.body: Hi annevk, that is the documentation I am studying these days, however I have just started and I would like to understand better what is a "navigable", what is 'something active' (for example when talking about session history entry) and some other concepts are used there
navigable and session history aren't mentioned in the DOM spec. Are you looking at the HTML spec?

That's right. Sorry for the misunderstanding.

This is the url I'm reading from: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#navigation-and-session-history

foolip: I'm curious about the idea of converting the HTML spec to Bikeshed. I wonder if the HTML spec is too 'weird' to express in Bikeshed format, but I'm not familiar enough with the latter yet.
content.formatted_body: foolip: I'm curious about the idea of converting the HTML spec to Bikeshed. I wonder if the HTML spec is too 'weird' to express in Bikeshed format, but I'm not familiar enough with the latter yet.

content.body: It might need some pre- or post-processing, but I don't think it's that weird in other ways than size

Agreed. HTML used to be in terms of Anolis, which is what Bikeshed in terms of format is also loosely derived from. (And as I mentioned above it's been converted to Bikeshed before. Just not in a way that lasted or could be properly reviewed.)
Did the CSS specification preprocessor have a name of sorts? I think that was used before these tools, but it's hard to find now.
"Bert's postprocessor"?
That's not wrong. 😀

smaug: half 😀. I'm in all day meetings but I can do some async replying
content.formatted_body: @smaug:mozilla.org: half 😀. I'm in all day meetings but I can do some async replying

content.body: Jake Archibald: just a random spec question. Is there some clear documentation what is navigable and what is traversable navigable , and when is a navigable not traversable navigable?
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: just a random spec question. Is there some clear documentation what is navigable and what is traversable navigable , and when is a navigable not traversable navigable?

content.body: smaug: from memory, the traversable is the thing that owns the history entries. So, an iframe is not traversable, because it's the top level that traverses. It'd be nice to have traversable iframes at some point, but they don't exist right now
content.formatted_body: @smaug:mozilla.org: from memory, the traversable is the thing that owns the history entries. So, an iframe is not traversable, because it's the top level that traverses. It'd be nice to have traversable iframes at some point, but they don't exist right now

content.body: Eg when you back() an iframe it's just telling the top level to go back (if it's allowed to)
But there is separately top-level traversable
Hmmmmm maybe I need to refresh my memory of the spec

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/document-sequences.html#top-level-traversables

> Currently, all traversable navigables are top-level traversables. Future proposals envision introducing non-top-level traversables.
content.formatted_body:
https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/document-sequences.html#top-level-traversables

Currently, all traversable navigables are top-level traversables. Future proposals envision introducing non-top-level traversables.

content.body: So yeah, it'd be "traversable iframes", if we ever get those, that would be traversables that are not top level
Ok, this is massively confusing. I guess need to get rid of some definition
I mean, I think traversable iframes would be massively valuable, but if folks want to remove that possibility from the spec now, sure
let's add definitions once they are needed for something
But ok, thanks for clarifying this
yea right now traversable navigable and top-level traversable are synonomous AFAIU
(I've read those same definitions every now and then and they are always just as hard to understand 😉 )
When I need to touch that part of the HTML standard I start the day by saying "traversable navigable" three times in a row fast as a tooth-strengthening exercise
Is traverables vs navigables confusing? In that traversables have history state, and the intended position in history, whereas navigables just get told which history entry to use
I think we should do that. The standard is already complicated enough, it shouldn't have terms things that don't yet exist
The old model was definitely simpler but didn't really cover reality (and there was many bugs as a result)
It's two new 4-syllable words that are not in day to day use
Anyway, not suggesting to rename those terms, but it's indeed not easy
There may be better names out there for "thing that traverses" and "thing that navigates"
But I couldn't think of anything else that described that distinction
I agree it's a bit "thennable"
